text:
Two or three years—a total mess, and her life’s done by eighteen or nineteen. 😟 I’ve seen this happen before. How do they end up like that? They all seem to go down that path. Ugh! But who cares? They say it’s just how it is. Apparently, a certain percentage has to fall… that way… to hell, I guess, so the rest can stay pure and not get bothered. A percentage! Such fancy words—so scientific, so comforting. Once you throw out “percentage,” you stop worrying. If we had a different term… maybe we’d feel more uneasy. But what if Dounia is part of that percentage? Or another one, if not this one?

“Where am I headed?” he suddenly thought. “Weird, I came out for something. After reading the letter, I stepped out… I was going to Vassilyevsky Ostrov, to Razumihin. That’s it… now I remember. But why did I think of Razumihin just now? That’s odd.”

He was surprised by himself. Razumihin was one of his old buddies from university. It’s notable that Raskolnikov had almost no friends there; he kept to himself, didn’t visit anyone, and didn’t welcome visitors. Eventually, everyone just stopped trying. He skipped the student hangouts, parties, and chats. He worked super hard, pushing himself, and earned respect for it, but no one really liked him. He was broke, and he carried this air of pride and distance, like he was hiding something.

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Raskolnikov reflects on the societal acceptance of moral decay and his own isolation from peers while contemplating a visit to Razumihin.
